awd_titl_txt: Well-posedness and Behavior of Solutions to Kinetic Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop new analytic and computational methods to solve a variety of mathematical problems in the kinetic theory of plasma dynamics. Plasmas are often referred to as the fourth state of matter (after solids, liquids, and gases) and account for 99.99% of all material in the universe. Since plasmas are charged gases, they serve as excellent conductors of electricity, and thus are of great practical interest. As an example, plasma engines have been developed by a number of space agencies and recently used to power some NASA spacecraft. Additionally, the use of plasmas within nuclear fusion as a source of clean energy is currently of immense scientific interest.  Other notable examples of plasmas include the solar wind, the Earth's ionosphere, galactic nebulae, and comet tails. A complete understanding of the solar wind would also be particularly useful, as this natural phenomenon dictates the intensity of "space weather", which is often responsible for expensive damage to satellites orbiting the Earth. In general, the motion of a plasma is described by a number of complicated partial differential equations dictated by physics. Among the goals of the current project are to demonstrate that these equations possess realistic solutions, determine their qualitative behavior, compute their sensitivity with respect to model parameters (such as masses, charges, and temperature), and computationally approximate them so that one can accurately predict outcomes in future situations.


A plasma is a fully ionized gas in which electromagnetic forces are often strong enough to dominate collisional effects. The motion of a high temperature, low density collisionless plasma is described by the Vlasov-Maxwell equations, a nonlinear system of hyperbolic partial differential equations. In this setting, collisions are neglected while the charge and current densities, which drive the Maxwell system, are determined in a self-consistent manner from velocity averages of solutions to the Vlasov equation. One major question this project will study is: are there shocks in a collisionless plasma? That is, could a singularity develop from smoothly prescribed initial values as time progresses? In some cases, such as in lower dimensional, relativistic formulations (e.g., one space and two velocity variables), smooth global solutions are known to exist.  Similarly, the associated Fokker-Planck system will be studied to further elucidate the smoothing influence of collisions on the particle distribution. Another problem to be investigated concerns the long-time behavior of the charge density and electromagnetic field in the system.  More specifically, do dispersive effects in the equations cause these quantities to decay over time, or is there sufficient interaction so as to sustain their strength even as time tends to infinity?  Finally, the sensitivity of fields and densities with respect to model input parameters will be computed using global sensitivity metrics and particle-in-cell simulations.

por.por_cntn:
Kinetic models are ubiquitous throughout applied mathematics with a storied history dating back to Boltzmann, Grad, and the initial development of statistical mechanics. Today, Kinetic Theory is a rich field that acnhors a variety of applications to gas dynamics, plasma physics, astrophysics, semiconductor theory, space physics, quantum mechanics, nuclear engineering, and green energy research. The analytical and computational challenges inherent within these problems originate in the need to resolve particle motion in high-?dimensional phase spaces and over large domains, which is usually analytically challenging and computationally prohibitive.

 

The primary goal of the project was to obtain mathematically precise statements about these models by applying techniques from the realms of classical analysis, a priori estimation, and nonlinear differential equations. Such results impact the underlying physical science by validating or invalidating the models of interest, displaying limits on their range of applicability, producing qualitative estimates which aid in the construction and analysis of numerical methods, and increasing the scientific understanding of the phenomena of interest. These goals were overwhelmingly achieved as the PI, along with a variety of collaborators, developed several new analytical methods that are quite effective in the study of kinetic equations. To date, 16 journal articles have been published quoting partial support from this grant. A few highlights of the major achievements include:

(1) The first study of the spatially-homogeneous and isotropic Vlasov-Einstein-Fokker-Planck system resulting in a precise criterion that identifies the exact longtime dynamics of solutions and categorizes this behavior based upon differing regimes of intial data.

(2) The first development of global smooth solutions to the fundamental non-?relativistic model of plasma dynamics -? the Vlasov-?Maxwell system -? in a reduced phase space.

(3) The first proof that collisionless plasmas may display arbitrarily large decay times. Namely, given an arbitrarily small initial charge density, as well as, a chosen time T and chosen value P, we may construct a solution whose charge density at time T is larger than the given threshold P. This result implies an analogous theorem for the strength of the corresponding electric field, and demonstrates that interesting and complex intermediate behavior exists within such systems. 

(4) The construction and implementation of Active Subspace methods to perform global sensitivty analyses of quantities in kinteic models as functions of input parameters. These computational methods have been used to conduct rigorous sensitivity studies of the exponential decay of the electric field within an electrostatic plasma undergoing Landau damping and the growth of perturbations from unstable equilibria. Our methods measure the change in the damping (or growth) rate with respect to the plasma's average and thermal velocities and the amplitude and frequency of the perturbation from equilibrium and then determine the directions within the parameter space that contribute most to the greatest fluctuations of this quantity. 

(5) The establishment of precise estimates on the longtime behavior of solutions to the Vlasov-Poisson system for both non-relativistic and relativistic models arising from spherically-symmetric initial data. In particular, the optimal polynomial decay rates for the charge density and electric field were identified and proved, while the exact asymptotic behavior of all particle trajectories in the system was obtained. Furthermore, the uniform convergence of the spatial average of the particle distribution to a scattering mass was proved as t tends to infinity. The existence of this scattering mass further induces a limiting electric field that was used to identify particle trajectroies in phase space along which the particle distribution converges to a limiting function as t to goes to infinity.

 

Project results in these directions have been widely disseminated in the form of 15 seminars, conference talks, and colloquia presented by the PI and another 20 by collaborators, including students involved in the research developments. During the funding period, the PI has trained four Ph.D. students, three M.S. students, and two undergraduate students to perform extensive research in this area. Two Ph.D. students have completed their degrees by August 2020, while the others will do so over the next two years. Of the three M.S. students, all have completed their degrees - one works in industry for an energy solutions corporation, while the other two are currently pursuing PhDs at Colorado State and UC Irvine, respectively. Finally, the undergraduates have both graduated, and one is currently attending graduate school in applied mathematics.

 

In summary, the thrust of our research involved the use mathematical tools to prove rigorous theorems that guide the design and analysis of advanced numerical algorithms for applications in plasma physics, stellar dynamics, and nuclear engineering, among other fields. The results of these research projects will further enable accurate and efficient long-?time simulations of complex physical phenomena on high-?performance parallel computing architectures.
